A blackbox in the car ?

U.S. road planners are looking for a source of money to repair the declining highway system , and believe they have found the solution in a small black box that can be placed on the dashboard of each car .

The devices that record every kilometre of driving and report the information to the authorities are at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and the states ’ planning offices to revise the outdated system of financing US roads .
The normally rather boring area of road planning has suddenly sparked an intense debate with colourful alliances .

Libertarians have allied themselves with environmental groups , arguing that the government can use the small boxes to record the driven kilometres – and possibly where they were driven – and then use the information to calculate tax modes .
The Tea Party is horrified .
The American Civil Rights Association ( ACLU ) is also deeply concerned and expresses a number of data protection concerns .
But , while Congress cannot agree on action , several states no longer wait .
They are currently examining how they can switch over the next ten years to a system where drivers pay per mile . .
Thousands of motorists have already tested the tachographs , some of which are equipped with GPS monitoring . .
That really is a must for our country .

“ It is nothing we may only use , ” said Hasan Ikhrata , Managing Director of the Southern California Assn. of Governments , who plans to record the miles driven by all Californian drivers in the state from 2025 onwards .
The way we pay these taxes will change .
The technology is there .
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund , financed from taxes paid by Americans at the fuel pillar , is defaulting .
But America is no longer tanked as much as it used to be .
Cars use less petrol .
The government oil tax of 18.4 cents per gallon ( less than 4 euro cents per litre ) has not increased for 20 years .
At high injection prices , politicians do not dare to raise taxes by just one cent .
“ The tax on petrol is simply not sustainable , ” says Lee Munnich , an expert in transport legislation at the University of Minnesota .
Its state recently equipped 500 cars with tachographs to test a mile-based payment system .
“ This is the most meaningful alternative in the long run , ” he said .
Bureaucrats call it a mile-based user fee .

Not surprisingly , the idea has been applauded by urban liberals , for example , because the tax could be used to influence driving behaviour in such a way as to reduce congestion and harmful emissions .
The Californian planners are relying on the system to develop strategies to achieve the ambitious statutory objectives of the federal state on climate change .
But the Republican Bill Shuster from Pennsylvania , Chairman of the House Transportation Committee , has also stated that he is the most viable long-term alternative .
The free marketers of the Reason Foundation are also encouraged by the idea of having drivers pay after the route reached .
“ This is not a tax that disappears in a black hole , ” explains Adrian Moore , Vice President of Reason ’ s Guidelines .
People pay directly for what they get .
The movement is also supported by two former US Transport Ministers , who in a 2011 report called on Congress to move toward mile-based accounting .
The US Senate approved a $ 90 million pilot project last year , which would have included 10,000 cars .

But the majority in the House prevented the move and thus responded to the concerns of rural MEPs , who represent people who often have to go many miles on their way to work or to the city in their daily lives .
Nonetheless , several states and major cities are moving in this direction on their own .
The most committed is Oregon , which currently recruits 5,000 drivers for the country ’ s biggest experiment .
These drivers will soon pay the mileage fees instead of the oil tax to the state .
Nevada has already completed a pilot project .
New York City is also considering this .
Illinois tests it to a limited extent with trucks .

And the I-95 coalition , which includes the Transport Ministries of 17 states on the east coast ( including Maryland , Pennsylvania , Virginia , and Florida ) , is currently investigating how to introduce the change .
The concept is not a universal hit .
In Nevada , where recently 50 volunteers were equipped with the equipment , drivers were sceptical about the idea that the government could pursue each of its movements .
“ Concerns about Big Brother and such things were a big problem , ” explains Alauddin Khan , Head of Strategy and Earnings Management at the Transport Ministry of Nevada .
People did not want it .
When the test started , Nevada ’ s ACLU warned : “ It would be relatively easy to turn tachographs into adult monitoring devices . ”
There is no need to build a huge , bulky technological infrastructure that would inevitably be used to collect data about the daily movements of individuals .
Nevada is part of a series of states that are now looking for affordable technology with which the state can capture the driven kilometres , but not exactly when and where .
That , Khan said , would also reassure the public .
Hunting for this technology has led some authorities to a small startup company called True Mileage in California .
The company originally failed to help states tax drivers .
Rather , it was their aim to foot in an emerging market for car insurance , where drivers should pay on the basis of the miles driven .
But the devices it tested are also interesting for road planners , because they do not work with GPS and provide only limited information that is uploaded regularly by modem .
“ People are more willing to participate if their speed and sites are not recorded , ” said Ryan Morrison , Managing Director of True Mileage .
Some of these public pilot programmes have made major mistakes .
There are much cheaper and less intrusive ways of implementing this .
In Oregon , the planners experiment with giving drivers a number of choices .
You can choose a device with or without GPS .

Other bodies hope to be able to sell the concept of a suspicious public by providing the devices with more functions than few .

“ Drivers would be motivated to participate by the added value of the benefits offered by the system , ” says a city planning document .

The start is expected to be 2028 and 2034 .

A total of four major questions have been chosen by the Esa , to which the missions of the 2007 Cosmic Vision programme will find answers .
What are the conditions for the emergence of planets and lives ?
The exact events of the emergence of stars from large gas clouds - and thus the emergence of planets surrounding these stars - are still in the proverbial dark .
A large infrared telescope in space could penetrate this dark .
And if a star has a planet , under what circumstances can life arise there ?
To address this issue , the 2017 space telescope " Cheops " will be launched , with which 500 already known planetary systems will be examined more closely in our surroundings .
The possibilities are limited , however , and cheops are a small mission with a budget of EUR 150 million .

With larger instruments , astronomers could map earth-like planets and even analyze the composition of their atmospheres , searching for " biomarkers " : gases that are considered to be an indication of biological activity .
How does the solar system work ?
This issue , too , is ultimately intended to provide information on the conditions for the emergence of life .
An important role is the magnetic activity of a star and the interaction of its magnetic field as well as the particle radiation that it generates with the planetary system .
In our solar system these processes can be examined exemplary .
With the " Solar Orbiter " , the Esa has already granted a M class mission ( there the budget is about half a billion euros ) for this issue .
The probe will start in 2017 and closely monitor the surface and activity of the sun .
Jupiter and his moons are of great interest to researchers .
They want to find out what role the giant planet played in the development of the solar system .
The Esa provides for the first of the three L-missions of the Cosmic Vision program . the the the the .
The probe " Juice " ( Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer ) is expected to start its journey in 2022 .
Eight years later , she reached Jupiter and was to investigate the atmosphere of the planet and the icy moons of Europe , Kallisto and Ganymed .
What are the basic physical laws of the universe ?
Space offers many opportunities to study matter under extreme conditions and to investigate whether the laws of nature known to us are still valid there .
Perhaps there are also deviations that could show physicists the way to a new theory under which all known laws of nature can be united .
What has the universe emerged and what is it ?
13.7 billion years ago our cosmos came into being through the big bang .

Besides the common matter that consists of stars , planets and living creatures like us , there is dark matter , whose gravity holds galaxies and galaxy clusters together , and dark energy , through whose actions the expansion of space accelerates .
So far , researchers do not know which physical laws were valid in the first fractions of the big bang , nor what dark matter and dark energy consist of .
With " Euclid " , the Esa has already approved a M mission , which is scheduled to start in 2020 .

With a special telescope , the probe is designed to investigate the distribution of material in the universe for the first time throughout the sky , thus enabling conclusions on the nature of dark matter and dark energy .

Four other proposals are still competing for the second L-mission : a large X-ray telescope called " Athena " , which is intended to explore , among other things , black holes , " Icy Planets " , another mission to the outer planets of the solar system , " Prism " , a mission to measure the cosmic background radiation , and the " Exoplanet Finder " , which is intended to detect and investigate earth-like planets .

For 21 years , Georges Bwelle saw his sick father losing consciousness and travelling to hospitals that did not have the means to help him .
Jamef Bwelle was injured in 1981 in a car accident near Yaoundé , the capital of Cameroon .

“ There were no neurosurgeons in Cameroon , ” says Georges Bwelle .
We would have brought him out of Cameroon if we had the money .
Instead , Bwelle spent years accompanying his father in overcrowded clinics and hospitals to get the treatment they had to offer .
“ It is not easy , ” comments Bwelle .
You can leave the house at 5 o 'clock in the morning and race to the hospital to be the first , and is not the first .
There are many patients .
Some people even die because they have to wait .
The situation has hardly changed since Bwelle ’ s father died in 2002 .
In Cameroon there is only one doctor for 5,000 people each , according to the World Health Organization .
On the other hand , the relationship in the United States is with a doctor for 413 people .
But even if there were a doctor for them , most cameruns could not afford to visit .
Two out of five people in the country live below the poverty line , and nearly three-quarters of domestic health spending is private .
“ The only problem they have is poverty , ” says Bwelle .
And poverty makes it impossible to enjoy life .
His father and so many of his compatriots suffered to see in Bwelle the decision to do something about it matured .
Dr. Georges Bwelle and his volunteer performed 700 free operations last year .
He himself became a doctor and worked as a vascular surgeon at the Central Hospital in Yaoundé .
He also founded a non-profit organization called ASCOVIME , which travels to rural areas on weekends and offers free medical care .
Since 2008 he and his volunteer group have helped nearly 32,000 people .
Almost every Friday , he and up to 30 people are forced into small buses and drive with the heated medical equipment on the roof over unattached terrain to the villages that need help .
It is not always smooth .
They had to push the vehicles through rivers and mud for more than once .
But when they arrive , they will be received like heroes : a festive dinner , singing and dance and the best accommodation that the place has to offer .
In these villages , free medical care is really a reason to celebrate and celebrate – with its broad smile and its limitless energy – enjoy the happy celebration .
The next morning the team begins to investigate hundreds of patients .
“ We treat 500 people per ride ” , says Bwelle .
They come from a 60 kilometre radius around the village – and that is on foot .
Each of these weekend clinics offers medical care in a number of areas .
Many people are treated for malaria , tuberculosis , malnutrition , diabetes , parasites and sexually transmitted diseases .
Others receive crutches , donated glasses , or free birth certificates – a document that is required for the school , but that many poor families simply cannot afford .
In the evening , the team performs simple operations with local anaesthesia .
Operations usually take place in a school , the town hall or an apartment ; after the surgery , patients are up and go to the recreation area to make room for the neighbor .
The lighting for the OP and disinfection equipment is fed by the group 's generator and so Bwelle and its volunteers work until the early morning hours on Sunday .
It is an exhausting pension , but the village musicians usually help keep the team motivated .
“ You drum all night so that we can stay awake and continue our work , ” says Bwelle .
On Sunday the team then returns to the city , tired but proud of the work done .

The group – a mixture of Cameroon doctors and foreign medical students – carried out 700 free operations last year and knows that , with its work , it causes a huge difference to the people it helps .
One man explained that the free operation of a crash that he received now allows him to work again .
“ This changes the future of my family , ” the man said .
Besides the weekend clinics and his work as a surgeon in the hospital , Bwelle also works at night in private clinics in Yaoundé .
With this second job he financed 60 % of his non-profit activity , Bwelle said ; the rest come from private donations .
“ I really do not know when he sleeps , ” says Katie O 'Malley , who studied medicine at Drexel University in Philadelphia in the second year and volunteers in Bwelles Group .

Students normally pay their trip to Cameroon themselves and bring frequently donated sanitary material .
